history.content:
I'm thinking of doing the same thing, and honestly it shouldn't affect you negatively. These are unique times, so grad schools should if anything see it as a positive thing that you still put in your best effort and did well in your other classes. Assuming your grades stay relatively the same as they have been this year, grad schools will probably interpolate your missing grades, rather than assuming the worst and punishing you for trying to excel in your other classes.

And if a school doesn't care about your performance overall and chooses to hone in on the one class you take DPN in your four years here, is that school really worth it?

That was my thought process, and I personally realized that I wouldn't want to go to a school that sees a DPN and just assumes the worst for one class if I manage to stay consistent for the rest of college. Hopefully this helps you drive your own decision too though!

children.subject: Yeah, I think that might look like you're taking advantage of the system. It's doubtful anyone will really look at grades from this semester, but just in case, I'd either pnp everything or take everything graded.
In a similar note, would it look bad for grad schools if I P/NP-ed 16A but kept my breadths/R1B/170 as letter graded? Should I just do all P/NP instead?

history.content: I was thinking of using the default pnp for my eecs16b but not use it for other courses. I am a freshman and was thinking of grad school so I was wondering how much it would matter as I might take a gpa hit if I don’t pnp.
history.subject: Default pnp
